awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P: Towards Preparing Future Machinists: Exploring Tacit Knowledge in Machining with Artificial Intelligence and Extended Reality
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates how to capture and pass on tacit knowledge in machining. Experienced machinists have a great deal of tacit knowledge that is essential for their decision-making, but such knowledge is personal, context-specific, and consequently difficult to acquire, as well as to formalize and communicate to others. This both complicates training new machinists and risks losing this tacit knowledge entirely as experienced machinists born in the post World War II baby boom retire. To address these challenges, the project team will investigate to what extent, and how, tacit knowledge in machining can be identified, understood, and transferred with the help of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Virtual/Augmented Reality (XR). The work in this project development grant will lead to a better understanding of experienced machinists’ tacit knowledge and how it is applied in their work. It will also generate new ideas for AI techniques that recognize tacit knowledge and XR-based training systems and evaluation metrics; these will form the basis of future research that supports U.S. strategic plans around preparing the workforce for manufacturing industries.

The project will expand a convergent team of researchers from multiple disciplinary backgrounds, including engineering, learning sciences, computer science, game design/gamification, psychology, and workforce development. The proposed research is structured around three fundamental thrusts: (1) A human-subject research pipeline will be developed and applied to key stakeholders to understand the types of tacit knowledge and the ways in which tacit knowledge is acquired and utilized. (2) AI and XR techniques will be explored to understand, identify, and transfer tacit knowledge. (3) Cognitive models will be established to evaluate human performance in XR training and the credibility and acceptance of the training. The project team will pay special attention to developing ideas that can make the machining occupation more accessible to populations that are currently under-represented in this field, working with partners at a nearby school that teaches machining to deaf and hard of hearing students. The overarching goal of this research is to deepen the understanding of tacit knowledge in machining and support new directions for machining training, while developing the techniques in general ways that might be applied to training in domains beyond machining.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Goal 1 Key deliverables: A series of key ideas and principles shared with each team member; the key insights from both academics and industry, and clearer directions to perform the next tasks. 

What we achieved: 

  • We have built up the team and developed a full research proposal to be submitted to the next stage. 

  • We collected feedback from local trainers and industry partners at the multi-disciplinary symposium, on December 9, 2022. The feedback verified the necessary of proposed research tasks and consolidated the details of the experiments.

Goal 2 key deliverables: A deepened understanding of tacit knowledge in machining with detailed information; A qualitative research framework for studying tacit knowledge in machining.  

What we achieved:

  • Protocols for the interview and experiment to elicit tacit knowledge qualitatively. 

  • A workflow with a think-aloud conversation and a classical qualitative interview aiming to elicit five constructs (see Fig.1) that emerged from an exploratory literature review: Domain purpose, Domain Values and priorities, Domain Functions, Physical functions, Physical objects (Multimodality), and Reflective Practice (Past Experience used to real-time problem solving). 

  • Preliminary outcomes through interviews with two machinists. We found that machinists perceive a gap between what is learned in machining classes and the actual practices of machining and a necessity of visualizing machining steps to make a mental model of what machines are doing step by step.

Goal 3 key deliverables: A comprehensive understanding of tacit knowledge in tool wear; A preliminary machine learning framework for extracting auditory tacit knowledge. A preliminary gamification mechanism to gamify tacit knowledge in VR-based training; a prototyping VR-based training system with auditory tacit knowledge included.

What we achieved:

  • A preliminary experimental setup for acquiring multimodal data in tool wear tasks (see Fig. 2)

  • A preliminary vision language model (VLM) machine learning framework for extracting knowledge from both trainers’ verbal descriptions and actions. 

  • A preliminary XR system with both VR and AR modules (see Fig. 3 (a) and (b))

  • A preliminary performance evaluation and feedback module is implemented to incorporate the gamification element (see Fig. 3 (c), (d)).

Goal 4 key deliverables: A framework for training performance evaluation on VR-based machining training; the positive and negative impact of the different transfers of training on the performance. 

What we achieved: We conducted a cognitive work analysis (CWA) to analyze the tool wear task, which produced a decision ladder (see Fig. 4). 

Publications:

  • Ojeda-Ramirez, S., Yong, Z., Peppler, K., Zhang, Y., Peng, C., Rantanen, E., & Liu, R. (2023). Towards a Qualitative Assessment of Tacit Knowledge in Machining. In Proceedings of the International Conference of the Learning Sciences (in process). Buffalo, NY.

  • Yang, W., Dengxiong, X., Wang, X., Hu, Y., & Zhang, Y. (2024). “I can see your password”: A case study about cybersecurity risks in mid-air interactions of mixed reality-based smart manufacturing applications. Journal of Computing and Information Science in Engineering, 24(3), 031004.

  • Yang, W., & Zhang, Y. (2024). A Global Correction Framework for Camera Registration in Video See-Through Augmented Reality Systems. Journal of Computing and Information Science in Engineering, 24(3), 031003.

Presentation & Invited Talks:

  • Zhang, Y., Peppler, K., Peng, C., Rantanen, E., & Liu, R. (2023). Towards Preparing Future Machinists: Exploring Tacit Knowledge in Machining with Artificial Intelligence and Extended Reality. Poster presented at the FW-HTF Conference.

Outreach:

  • We co-organized ManufactuRIT 2023 Summer Camp (see Fig. 5).

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2024
Modified by: Yunbo Zhang

por.por_txt_cntn:
Goal 1 Key deliverables: A series of key ideas and principles shared with each team member; the key insights from both academics and industry, and clearer directions to perform the next tasks.


What we achieved:




We have built up the team and developed a full research proposal to be submitted to the next stage.




We collected feedback from local trainers and industry partners at the multi-disciplinary symposium, on December 9, 2022. The feedback verified the necessary of proposed research tasks and consolidated the details of the experiments.




Goal 2 key deliverables: A deepened understanding of tacit knowledge in machining with detailed information; A qualitative research framework for studying tacit knowledge in machining.


What we achieved:




Protocols for the interview and experiment to elicit tacit knowledge qualitatively.




A workflow with a think-aloud conversation and a classical qualitative interview aiming to elicit five constructs (see Fig.1) that emerged from an exploratory literature review: Domain purpose, Domain Values and priorities, Domain Functions, Physical functions, Physical objects (Multimodality), and Reflective Practice (Past Experience used to real-time problem solving).




Preliminary outcomes through interviews with two machinists. We found that machinists perceive a gap between what is learned in machining classes and the actual practices of machining and a necessity of visualizing machining steps to make a mental model of what machines are doing step by step.




Goal 3 key deliverables: A comprehensive understanding of tacit knowledge in tool wear; A preliminary machine learning framework for extracting auditory tacit knowledge. A preliminary gamification mechanism to gamify tacit knowledge in VR-based training; a prototyping VR-based training system with auditory tacit knowledge included.


What we achieved:




A preliminary experimental setup for acquiring multimodal data in tool wear tasks (see Fig. 2)




A preliminary vision language model (VLM) machine learning framework for extracting knowledge from both trainers verbal descriptions and actions.




A preliminary XR system with both VR and AR modules (see Fig. 3 (a) and (b))




A preliminary performance evaluation and feedback module is implemented to incorporate the gamification element (see Fig. 3 (c), (d)).




Goal 4 key deliverables: A framework for training performance evaluation on VR-based machining training; the positive and negative impact of the different transfers of training on the performance.


What we achieved: We conducted a cognitive work analysis (CWA) to analyze the tool wear task, which produced a decision ladder (see Fig. 4).


Publications:




Ojeda-Ramirez, S., Yong, Z., Peppler, K., Zhang, Y., Peng, C., Rantanen, E., & Liu, R. (2023). Towards a Qualitative Assessment of Tacit Knowledge in Machining. In Proceedings of the International Conference of the Learning Sciences (in process). Buffalo, NY.




Yang, W., Dengxiong, X., Wang, X., Hu, Y., & Zhang, Y. (2024). I can see your password: A case study about cybersecurity risks in mid-air interactions of mixed reality-based smart manufacturing applications. Journal of Computing and Information Science in Engineering, 24(3), 031004.




Yang, W., & Zhang, Y. (2024). A Global Correction Framework for Camera Registration in Video See-Through Augmented Reality Systems. Journal of Computing and Information Science in Engineering, 24(3), 031003.




Presentation & Invited Talks:




Zhang, Y., Peppler, K., Peng, C., Rantanen, E., & Liu, R. (2023). Towards Preparing Future Machinists: Exploring Tacit Knowledge in Machining with Artificial Intelligence and Extended Reality. Poster presented at the FW-HTF Conference.




Outreach:




We co-organized ManufactuRIT 2023 Summer Camp (see Fig. 5).
